issue.body:
I have been using the {{yield}} helper extensively to build some reusable controls, and it works great.  However, sometimes when a control is used, it may not need to specify a block to be yielded.  Ember currently requires a block to be specified.  If you write a view containing a {{yield}} block as...

```
{{view View.With.Yield}}
```

... it will throw:

```
You called yield on [view] without supplying a template
```

You can work around it today by writing it as:

```
{{#view View.With.Yield}}{{/view}}
```
This works because an empty template is created... but this seems unnecessary from both a coding standpoint and a performance standpoint.

This pull request prevents the exception from being thrown and instead simply renders nothing when {{yield}} is specified without a corresponding block.

The {{yield}} functionality certainly seems to be inspired by Ruby's implementation of yielding, and Ruby does not force a block to be specified.  In my opinion, Ember should not either.
issue.title: Makes yield blocks optional

comment.body:
Thanks for the quick response, Tom.

Well, before I get into examples, let me provide a little better context.  In my opinion, allowing empty yield blocks is more closely aligned with how {{view}} works in the first place.  In a Handlebars template, you can write only the following:

```
{{view}}
```

It will faithfully create an Ember view and output a div to the DOM.  The view does not have a "template" or "templateName" attribute, nor does it contain an inline template block.  Yet it works as expected... it does not throw an error telling you that you must define a template.

You can also define a view as:

```
{{#view}}this is the content{{/view}}
```

... and it will faithfully "yield" the content as expected.  So really, my suggestion is to make {{yield}} work more consistently with the way {{view}} works today.


Here is an example of where I've been bitten by this.  I have a view to display an alert.  It describes the div, sets the appropriate classes, includes an icon and a close button, but the message itself will obviously change based on the situation.  When the message is just text, I prefer setting or binding to a content property of the view, like most views do.  However, there are also times when I want to output markup and even some child views.  The {{yield}} functionality is ideal for this, because I can declare the content within its contextual template instead of having to create a different template, or worse, an entirely new view class.  Obviously there are other ways to accomplish the same goal, but in my opinion, if the framework is supporting {{yield}}, it should allow it to be optional.

A second example, along the same lines.  I have a generic "empty view" class that shows when a collection is empty that can describe what the items are and present a button for the user to create their first item.  It contains an image, a title, a button whose text is bound to a property, and then the description is yielded.  Again, {{yield}} is great here because it allows me to keep a consistent look-and-feel and keep my code DRY, while being able to allow for custom markup for the description.  But sometimes the description is just not necessary... the image, the title, and the button is plenty of information to the user.

I definitely agree that the framework should provide helpful error messages when it makes sense... I have been rescued by them many times myself.  I just don't believe that this is an occasion for one.  If someone creates a layout containing {{yield}} but makes the mistake of forgetting to provide the content, they will see the problem the moment the view is displayed and can then correct it.  In fact, I would contend that seeing the empty view on the screen would probably be more helpful to them than an error message.

I am a heavy Rails user with ERB templates, and yield is a way of life.  This is how they implemented it, and it has stood the test of time.  I firmly believe that if Ember is also going to support yielding, it should do the same.

issue.title: Makes yield blocks optional

pull_request.body:
This PR pulls the [App.contactsController](https://github.com/emberjs/examples/blob/master/contacts/app.js)'s 4 methods to keep the ArrayProxy sorted:

* add
* binarySearch
* remove
* contactSortValueDidChange

into a new wrapper class around ```ArrayProxy```. The methods are generalized.  If you indicate you will accept this pull request, I will be glad to update the  [App.contactsController](https://github.com/emberjs/examples/blob/master/contacts/app.js) to make the example easier to understand.

I've earnestly tried to put everything I can think of that's needed into automated regression tests and the API docs.  I hope you like it.  Thanks.  **OldFartDeveloper** w/ help from **Drew Purdy** and **James Gary**.
pull_request.title: Add an Ember.SortedArrayProxy class

comment.body: Can you describe the use case for this a little bit? I'd like to understand the cases where this is helpful. Obviously, there is some danger in doing this as people may have made a mistake, and we want to provide helpful error messages whenever possible.

issue.body:
Trying to figure out the "ember best practices" for my app, regarding models (ember-data)/controllers/views.  i'll use User as an example:

what I *feel* like I want to do is to get a User from the database... then wrap it in a UserController, and set the model on a "content" property...  then in a View, I want to bind to the controller for some functionality, and to the **controller.content.field** for model-level data.    so say the model had a property like "you_follow: true"... and the controller has something like:

    isFollowingBinding : 'content.you_follow',
    toggleFollow: function() {  make server call to change following flag }
    
and the view can use this


but say I get a list of Users back from the database...  I *feel* like I want to wrap each of those User models with a UserController, and then make that list of UserControllers available to the View

I've done this... and it is working nicely.... but everytime I reload the list, I re-wrap all of the new model objects with new controllers...  and over time, the # of controllers in memory seem to get larger and larger.   on my base Controller class, I'm logging calls to "destroy", and I dont see it happening

on the View side, I know the views are getting destroyed on every page redraw (I'm also using ember-layout and ember-route-manager... which use statemanager underneath).  so if I move my code into a view, i know it will get destroyed and recreated everytime... but I dont feel like the functionality like toggleFollow() is supposed to be in view... 


Am I thinking about things correctly... or am I off-base?   If models should be wrapped in controllers, and there could be lots of smaller controllers on a screen... how do I make sure they are garbage collected?   Or should what I'm thinking is a controller's actually be a view?

or is there some sort of garabage collection strategy I should be aware of, to make sure my Em.Objects are being cleaned up?

hopefully this makes sense....
issue.title: Controller Strategy / Garbage Collection (destroy)

comment.body: makes sense.. ok, will do.  thanks!

comment.body: I think you should ask your question on [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/emberjs) for 2 reasons: although it's fine to post questions here, SO is mainly used for QA and most questions get asked and more importantly answered there. The second reason is that another user who might have a similar problem to yours, will search on SO and most likely not in the issues on GitHub.

issue.body:
Trying to figure out the "ember best practices" for my app, regarding models (ember-data)/controllers/views.  i'll use User as an example:

what I *feel* like I want to do is to get a User from the database... then wrap it in a UserController, and set the model on a "content" property...  then in a View, I want to bind to the controller for some functionality, and to the **controller.content.field** for model-level data.    so say the model had a property like "you_follow: true"... and the controller has something like:

    isFollowingBinding : 'content.you_follow',
    toggleFollow: function() {  make server call to change following flag }
    
and the view can use this


but say I get a list of Users back from the database...  I *feel* like I want to wrap each of those User models with a UserController, and then make that list of UserControllers available to the View

I've done this... and it is working nicely.... but everytime I reload the list, I re-wrap all of the new model objects with new controllers...  and over time, the # of controllers in memory seem to get larger and larger.   on my base Controller class, I'm logging calls to "destroy", and I dont see it happening

on the View side, I know the views are getting destroyed on every page redraw (I'm also using ember-layout and ember-route-manager... which use statemanager underneath).  so if I move my code into a view, i know it will get destroyed and recreated everytime... but I dont feel like the functionality like toggleFollow() is supposed to be in view... 


Am I thinking about things correctly... or am I off-base?   If models should be wrapped in controllers, and there could be lots of smaller controllers on a screen... how do I make sure they are garbage collected?   Or should what I'm thinking is a controller's actually be a view?

or is there some sort of garabage collection strategy I should be aware of, to make sure my Em.Objects are being cleaned up?

hopefully this makes sense....
